23.96.text:
I'm Matt Olien sitting
 in for John Harris.

25.86.text:
My guest today is
   someone I've known

27.26.text:
for a long time, and he's
   achieved a great deal.

31.33.text: the United States Navy is here.

34.37.text:
- Thank you very much, Matt,
  great to be here with you.

35.84.text:
- Before we get started
   about a lot of the things,

37.54.text:
I wanna talk about
  Navy Week in Fargo.

40.14.text:
This is what you're here
for as we're taping.

42.08.text:
Just tell us folks
 about your background,

43.68.text:
where you're from originally,
 how you got involved

45.85.text:
and, you know, really why you
 chose the Navy as your career.

49.15.text:
- Sure, well, I
  grew up in a series

50.55.text: of four towns in North Dakota.

55.09.text:
And I ended up in
  Oakes, where I went

56.36.text: to junior high and high school,

57.66.text: and I now consider that home.

59.73.text:
While I was there I
 developed an interest

61.16.text:
in service academies,
 and at the time,

63.60.text:
Annapolis seemed to offer
   the most opportunities.

67.53.text:
So I put that first
  in my applications

69.94.text:
and was fortunate
   to be accepted.

71.60.text:
And then I went
   off there and had

75.44.text:
different choices for
  career choices in the Navy.

78.51.text:
And you have to
   remember back then

80.35.text:
the Cold War was still going,
 and the submarine force

83.42.text: is where the action really was.

85.52.text:
That was the hardest thing
   to do as well, so that was

87.85.text:
very appealing, and that's
   what I ended up doing.

90.02.text:
- Take me back, we'll get
  into Navy Week in a minute,

92.53.text:
but like in high school,
  you were a grade ahead of me

94.69.text:
at Oakes, and of
course we all are proud

96.63.text:
of what you've achieved, but
  take me back to high school.

98.67.text:
I remember when you started
 kind of applying to Annapolis.

101.50.text:
And a hard thing
to do, isn't it?

103.27.text:
Tell me about that process and
 really what was that decision

106.27.text:
cause, you know, you coulda
  went to a lot of colleges

108.17.text:
with your grades and
  everything, but what really

110.84.text:
got you on that kick to
  try to get in to Annapolis,

114.58.text:
and then tell us
   about the process

116.15.text: to get in cause it's not easy.

117.58.text:
- Sure, well actually
 the seed goes back

119.92.text: to when I was in junior high.

121.35.text:
My father mentioned one time
  he had done one enlistment

124.39.text:
in the Navy that his
  supervisors thought

128.66.text:
he might be interested, and
then discovered he was too old.

132.00.text: So he mentioned that story to me

133.40.text:
one time when I
  was in junior high,

134.90.text:
and that was the spark
that I then followed on.

137.70.text:
So I was pretty intent about
  going to a service academy

140.71.text:
when I was in high
   school, and they look for

143.44.text:
a well-rounded person
   more than just the grades.

147.48.text:
So I was very active in
 athletics and other activities

150.88.text:
while I was there,
   leadership opportunities,

155.19.text:
and so the application looks
 for those items in particular

159.59.text:
for the type of person
 they're looking for.

162.10.text:
So you fill out an application
 to the Naval Academy,

165.10.text:
and then in parallel
  you also apply

167.40.text:
for an appointment from
your elected officials,

170.94.text:
so you can apply to
 both senators and then

174.87.text:
Here in North Dakota
   traditionally those three

177.31.text:
will get together and
 have a combined board,

179.88.text:
and then they pick
   their nominees

181.51.text:
for those in the Naval
 Academy, who confirm

185.92.text:
and then the Academy will
   issue the appointments.

188.49.text:
- And just, if I can toot Oakes'
horn for a bit, we had two

192.69.text:
in two years, cause Mike
  Matthias went to West Point.

194.93.text:
He was a grade behind
 me, and he's had

197.33.text:
a wonderful career
   there as well.

199.13.text:
But it is hard to get in, and
 I know you had a great career.

202.10.text:
Wanna talk about your career
  in a minute, but I wanna get

204.00.text:
to Navy Week cause that's really
why, as we're taping this,

206.51.text:
you're here in Fargo
  for Fargo Navy Week.

208.41.text:
What is that and
   why are you here?

210.21.text:
And tell us about some
 of the activities.

211.95.text:
- Sure, so the Navy does 12
  weeks around the country,

216.68.text:
and we select areas
where there's generally

220.19.text:
strong support for
   the Armed Forces.

222.76.text:
And also an area where
 the Navy's not perhaps

224.89.text:
well as understood as
 the other branches.

227.53.text:
So here in the middle
 of the continent

229.06.text:
is a perfect place to appear,
 and the Fargo-Moorhead region

233.27.text:
of course has always been
  strong for the Armed Forces.

236.27.text:
So we'll spend a week here
   talking about the Navy,

238.64.text:
explaining the Navy,
   also a number of exhibits

245.75.text:
Kids events showing off some
of the technology that we have.

250.12.text:
The band is here
   to provide music,

253.45.text:
and then of course the Blue
  Angels here on the weekend.

256.76.text:
- Yeah, tell us about
 some of these robotics

258.83.text:
and things that kids
  can participate in

260.96.text:
and what you're doing and
 where you're going with that.

263.06.text:
- Sure, there's a couple
primary activities.

270.00.text:
the bomb squads if
  you will, use these

274.64.text:
Very similar to a police
 forces around the country now.

278.28.text:
And so they'll have
 those here to exhibit,

280.71.text:
and then they have some
  miniature versions of those

282.08.text:
for the kids to
   actually operate.

286.65.text:
a virtual reality display
   involving navigation

291.99.text:
in the undersea
   environment, and the kids

294.76.text:
really like that cause it's
  sort of close to gaming.

297.53.text:
But it's an actual simulator
  that we use for training.

300.87.text:
- How has the Navy changed
   over the years, Admiral?

302.70.text:
Because, I mean, you've
been on nuclear subs,

306.14.text:
you've commanded one, we'll
 get to that in a few minutes,

308.21.text:
but a lot of changes
   technologically since we,

311.91.text:
you and I growing up watching
 the World War 2 movies

314.31.text:
about the Navy, it's amazing
  the technology, right?

318.25.text:
- Yeah, so I would actually
  say not only technology

320.52.text:
but the people and then the
  operations that we conduct.

323.42.text:
So technology of course,
 things of course have advanced

327.66.text:
along with the rest of everyday
life with microprocessors

331.90.text:
and computers and
 everything that we do.

335.34.text:
And that really has
  enabled us to become

337.40.text:
that much better with the
   missions that we conduct.

341.44.text:
The people have
 actually gotten better

343.14.text: than what we used to have.

345.88.text:
The all-volunteer force when I
 started was still fairly new,

348.88.text:
and now it's mainstream
for what we do.

351.75.text:
It's quite extraordinary,
  the people that we attract.

354.75.text:
Only about 25% of high school
 graduates actually meet

357.99.text:
the minimum criteria for
   being in the Armed Forces

361.26.text:
for being physically fit
   and the academic aptitude

369.07.text:
So we really do get
  the best of America.

371.77.text:
And then operationally,
   of course, when I started

373.44.text:
as I mentioned it
  was in the Cold War.

375.84.text:
It's now different,
we're around the world,

377.48.text:
and we're focusing on
   many different hot spots.

381.18.text:
When you started, like
   you said, it was Cold War,

382.98.text:
so Soviet Union was
still kind of the focus.

385.92.text:
Tell me about that and
   then kinda take me through

388.96.text:
your career as well with your
 commands and things like that.

391.69.text:
- Sure, so when I
   started, the Soviet Union

393.43.text:
really was the singular focus
 of the United States Navy

396.83.text:
and the potential for
 warfare with them.

399.63.text:
And so when the
  wall fell in Berlin,

402.77.text:
things changed pretty
   markedly and very quickly.

406.64.text:
And we became more
diffuse in what we did,

410.48.text:
looking all around the
  world, controlling the seas,

413.05.text:
maintaining the sea
lanes free for shipping,

419.22.text:
And of course then we
had the Gulf War in '91,

423.69.text:
and then continued presence
  there maintaining civility,

427.06.text:
and now we're in an
 era where really it's

433.70.text:
We have concerns with Russia
  with what they've done

435.64.text:
in the Ukraine, and where they
 might be headed with that.

439.14.text:
Concerns with China and a
  very rapid military buildup.

442.88.text:
Some coercion in
  the South China Sea,

444.91.text:
and where they're
   headed with that.

447.95.text:
The Iranians the
potential for developing

454.72.text:
And then this long-term
terrorist threat,

457.42.text: and where that might be going.

459.36.text:
So it's really a
   multi-dimensional problem

462.53.text:
like we haven't
   dealt with before.

464.76.text:
- And how does the Navy fit
  into that, Admiral Munsch?

467.63.text:
Because I think the general
  public tends to think of

470.54.text:
Navy SEALs and the Marines
   and this kind of thing

474.34.text:
and ground troops, that
  tends to be what politically

476.68.text:
people talk about, you
   know, boots on the ground,

478.74.text:
this and that, should we
   commit boots on the ground

481.21.text:
to fight ISIS, et cetera,
  but what is the Navy's role,

483.65.text:
say, in the Middle East
or the South China Sea

486.05.text:
or things like that, up
in the Korean peninsula?

488.32.text:
- Sure, so about one
  third of the Navy

490.39.text:
is deployed overseas
  at any one time,

493.26.text:
and that's to all those areas
 that we just talked about.

496.03.text:
So by maintaining a
  continuous presence

498.33.text: in the area, there's two things.

500.27.text:
One is it deters
   any potential foe

505.57.text:
And then on the
   flipside of that,

507.11.text:
it assures allies and
friends that we're there

510.08.text:
to maintain civility, and
  so we're on the front lines.

514.01.text:
And if anything
   starts to go awry,

515.88.text:
we're usually the
 first ones to respond.

521.49.text:
- [Matt] Aircraft take off
 from ships, et cetera, right?

523.49.text:
- Exactly, and because we're
 based in international waters,

526.69.text:
we really have wide range of
 the earth, and we can operate

530.83.text:
from the seas and go
 ashore if we need to.

534.97.text:
So we often say those
 aircraft carriers

536.94.text:
are really four acres of
   sovereign U.S. territory.

541.61.text:
- Let em know we're
there, right? (laughing)

546.38.text:
When you first came
  out of the Navy,

549.65.text:
I know eventually, people
   are very interested,

551.38.text:
you commanded a nuclear
submarine, of course.

553.69.text:
Just take me
  through your career.

554.95.text:
Where it took you and
 the various commands.

557.96.text:
- Sure, I did a
 couple of odd things,

563.16.text:
this is not the normal
 path to do things.

566.07.text:
But I went straight
into graduate education

568.40.text:
after the Naval Academy,
and was very fortunate

570.57.text:
to be over at Oxford
 University in the U.K.

573.87.text:
Then it was time for me to
  play catch-up with my peers.

576.31.text:
So I did a ballistic missile
  submarine that carries

579.01.text:
the nuclear tip missiles,
   provides our nation

582.52.text:
strategic deterrence, and
   then I rolled straight

585.28.text:
into a fast attack
   submarine with deployments

587.69.text:
out in the Western
Pacific, and then I went

590.09.text:
to an aircraft carrier,
another unusual thing,

592.79.text:
and did a ployment with
   them to the Arabian Gulf,

596.26.text:
and then I was XO of a
submarine out in Hawaii

599.07.text:
with more operations
 in the Western Pacific

601.60.text:
and the Arabian Gulf, and
   then finally went ashore.

604.20.text:
Usually we don't spend
 that much time on sea.

607.34.text:
And I was at the
Pacific Command,

608.57.text:
which is headquartered
 there in Hawaii,

611.64.text:
and while there applied for
  a White House fellowship

614.25.text:
and was accepted, and
so I went off from there

617.45.text:
and spent a year
  in the White House.

619.32.text:
Another unusual
 thing to do, and then

621.45.text:
I went to command Albuquerque,
 the fast attack submarine.

624.76.text:
And that was based out
of Groton, Connecticut,

627.49.text:
and we deployed two times,
   once just in the Atlantic,

630.73.text:
and another time continuing
  on to the Arabian Gulf.

634.73.text:
That's then when I got my
first Pentagon tour after that,

638.14.text:
and it seems like now that's
  kinda my default place to be

641.21.text: when I'm not on the sea tour.

644.08.text:
And I've worked for the
  Deputy Secretary of Defense

646.31.text:
as his military
   assistant, and then I went

648.25.text:
to the Director of Submarine
  Warfare after that,

651.82.text:
which is the plans
   and policy office,

653.92.text:
budget office for
  the submarine force.

657.06.text:
And then commanded a
 squadron of submarines

659.96.text:
out in Washington State, then
 it was back to the Pentagon

663.36.text:
where I headed Navy
  strategy for a year

666.30.text:
and then was selected
 to become an admiral,

668.83.text:
and so I was back in the
submarine warfare office

672.00.text:
for two years and then out
   in Japan for two years,

676.14.text:
where I commanded all
our deployed submarines

677.68.text:
in the Western Pacific
and the Central Command

684.12.text:
And now I'm back
in the Pentagon,

685.79.text:
and again back working for the
 Deputy Secretary of Defense.

689.56.text:
What's it like to
   be deployed for

691.82.text: a long period of time on a sub?

693.93.text:
That must be really, you know,
 we've seen movies about it,

699.60.text:
That's gotta be stressful for
 some people, I would think,

702.44.text:
but what's it like to be in
command of something like that?

706.14.text:
- It's sort of the ultimate
  command in the Navy

712.98.text:
It's really quite a
 bit of responsibility

715.35.text:
to give an officer at
 the commander level

716.95.text:
to execute national policy
   and really be on his own.

720.35.text:
So it's very rewarding,
and our operations

724.59.text:
on fast attack submarines,
   which I've done primarily,

731.03.text:
We're continuously adding
  intelligence in peace time,

734.90.text:
and of course are
 ready with our weapons

738.74.text:
The longest we'll go is really
 limited by our food on board,

742.94.text:
and that's 90 days is a
   standard load-out of food.

749.85.text:
To a degree it can be a
 little bit like Groundhog Day

752.82.text:
for parts of the
  crew that are doing

754.35.text:
the same thing every day,
cause they don't all understand

758.16.text:
or are allowed to know the
  operations that we're doing.

761.39.text: But those of us that are doing

765.23.text:
- Is it something
   you get used to,

767.43.text:
being away from your
  family that long?

770.60.text:
Is there claustrophobia, is
 that something you're used to

772.74.text:
by the time you get command
  of something like that?

775.27.text:
Take me through the
mental strain, I guess.

778.04.text:
- Yeah, it's actually
 not that big a deal.

780.45.text:
- [Matt] It sounds like it
   is to me, or the layman.

784.12.text:
- Everybody who's in
  the submarine force

785.68.text:
is a volunteer, so those
that might have issues

788.62.text:
tend to self-select out
and do something else.

791.22.text:
And then if you start
  doing it when you're young,

792.96.text:
it's just sort of
 what you grow up with.

796.93.text:
So everybody does like to get
 out in the sun when we're done

800.63.text:
and the young sailors now,
  the other priority is to get

803.00.text:
on a Wi-Fi net and get
connected again with the world.

808.67.text:
Is it tough on the family
   to be away that long?

812.14.text:
Among the various
communities in the Navy,

814.68.text:
the submarine force is really
 known for close-knit families

817.08.text:
and strong support
   for one another,

819.49.text:
and that's really necessary
 with the business that we do.

822.45.text:
- You told me before
  we started recording

824.02.text:
you really liked
  your time in Japan.

827.06.text:
- I did, it's a
   wonderful country.

829.40.text:
The people unfailingly
are gracious and polite

832.57.text:
and go out of their
  way to assist you

834.87.text:
in any way that
   might be helpful.

836.97.text:
And it's a very orderly
society as well.

839.10.text:
Everything's very
 clean, no petty theft,

846.25.text:
Everything happens right when
 it's scheduled to happen,

848.91.text:
so it's really just a
 pleasure to live there

852.89.text:
- With Navy Week as we're
 here, is that really a chance

856.42.text:
for you guys to sell
the Navy to people too?

859.26.text:
This is what a Navy career
   is like, is that kind of

861.79.text: a PR thing for you guys as well?

863.80.text:
Tell me about that,
 maybe you're reaching

865.30.text:
maybe that kid who might
  choose the Navy as a career.

869.00.text:
- Yes, we do spend
 time explaining that.

871.47.text:
So it's an opportunity
 to see the world

874.51.text:
and go on deployments,
 things that you

876.24.text:
might not be able to do
here in North Dakota.

879.71.text:
It's an opportunity to pick
  up additional skillsets.

883.68.text:
Most of what we do involves
very high levels of technology,

895.13.text:
And then we also, in a
   very short period of time

899.50.text:
relative to regular life, do a
 lot in the way of leadership.

903.74.text:
So people who just do one
   enlistment in the Navy

906.57.text:
come away as great
   leaders as well.

909.81.text:
And then it's also a way to
  obtain a very good education

913.18.text:
without much expense, so with
 the GI you do one enlistment,

917.35.text:
and then you qualify
  for the GI Bill,

920.19.text:
and for all state
universities, that pays tuition

923.52.text:
and gives you a
   housing allowance,

925.93.text:
so it's quite a way to walk
away with additional skillsets,

929.66.text:
leadership, a full
  education and be debt free.

933.20.text:
- So while you're here will
you visit some schools as well?

935.50.text:
- I will, yes, I'll be meeting
 with the, schools are out

938.37.text:
in the summer, but
  I'll be meeting with

944.41.text:
- And I know the
 Chief of Naval Reserve

946.05.text: is with you this week as well.

947.51.text:
She's here, tell me about
   her and what she's up to,

951.38.text:
and what is the Naval
 Reserve actually too?

953.42.text: So just tell me about that.

955.02.text:
I know she's gonna be
here as well this week.

956.79.text:
- Sure, the Naval Reserve
   is a component of the Navy

961.99.text:
where those individuals
are of status

964.80.text: where they drill once per month,

967.97.text: and then spend a two week period

969.74.text:
on active duty in the
 course of the year.

972.07.text:
They belong to units
  that are dedicated

974.31.text:
to specific missions,
so when I was in Japan,

977.48.text:
I had a reserve
  unit assigned to me

979.55.text:
that specialized in
planning and operations.

982.95.text:
So they would help
   us plan events

985.42.text: that we were conducting at sea,

987.59.text:
and then when we did large
   exercises, they would fly

989.62.text:
over to Japan and help
 man my operations.

993.83.text:
And then we use them
  whenever there are

996.06.text: periods of conflict when we need

999.83.text:
- [Matt] Kind of like
 the National Guard.

1001.13.text:
- Exactly, and they
  come on active duty

1003.40.text:
and assist us with
that, and they all have

1006.87.text:
normal careers where they're
  doing something else,

1009.41.text:
and so that's also a source of
 special skills for the Navy.

1013.71.text:
So one of the individuals
 helping us here with Navy Week

1018.92.text:
lives here in Fargo,
  a Navy captain,

1021.29.text:
works in the IT field,
 and his Navy specialty

1024.32.text:
is in public affairs,
 and so, but he brings

1028.46.text: that IT skill also when he comes

1030.86.text:
on active duty and
  works with the Navy.

1033.43.text:
- And again I think the Chief
 of Naval Reserves is here.

1037.30.text:
- She's gonna be here
on Friday and Saturday.

1039.61.text:
She works in the
  Pentagon like I do,

1041.41.text:
but travels around
  a lot more than I do

1045.18.text:
and she's helping
celebrate the centennial

1047.21.text:
of the Naval Reserve,
 which is this year.

1049.58.text: - And I understand there's a lot

1052.55.text:
That's what kinda my
  information told me.

1054.59.text: A lot of in North Dakota too.

1056.69.text:
- Right, so there's a
  headquarters for the Reserve

1060.73.text:
of North Dakota is
here in the Fargo area,

1063.66.text:
and there are a few dozen
   reservists right here

1065.73.text:
in the Fargo area, and a few
  hundred across the state.

1069.13.text:
And then there are
several hundred veterans

1071.74.text:
that have retired here in
   the state from the Navy.

1074.57.text:
- Let's talk a little bit
  about the USS North Dakota,

1076.54.text:
that commissioning, because
 we had Bob Wefald on the show

1079.04.text:
and I know you were
  here a while ago

1081.98.text: and you were on our radio show.

1085.55.text:
and how Bob got it, he
   was really the spearhead,

1088.15.text:
and why it was
  named North Dakota.

1090.06.text:
- Yeah, so speaking
  of Naval Reservists,

1091.92.text:
Bob is a Naval Reservist,
   and for about 20 years

1095.56.text:
he worked the
  system, if you will,

1097.83.text:
to get a submarine named
after North Dakota,

1101.37.text:
which is the decision made
   by Secretary of the Navy.

1104.44.text: So it's quite a passion he had,

1106.81.text:
and it's tremendous
  for the state

1109.37.text:
that he was able
   to bring it about.

1111.41.text:
So USS North Dakota was
commissioned in October,

1113.68.text:
so that means it was placed
  in the service by the Navy.

1116.85.text:
It'll have a lifespan
 of about 33 years,

1120.15.text:
and it was the first
  of a new flight

1122.19.text:
of fast attack submarines and
 has some special capabilities.

1126.02.text:
Most notably, it has a couple
 of large diameter tubes

1130.83.text:
that are up in the bow, the
 forward part of the submarine,

1134.20.text:
and those can be used
as basically cannisters

1143.01.text:
or Navy Special
   Forces, the SEALs.

1146.55.text:
Or it's something maybe
   we don't know yet we need,

1149.18.text:
but it's a space where we
   can operate things from.

1152.72.text:
Submarines tend
   to be a bit larger

1154.89.text:
than people think that
   haven't been around them.

1157.82.text:
The USS North Dakota
  is 377 feet long

1161.69.text:
from the front end
   to the back end,

1163.10.text:
so it's longer than
  a football field,

1165.76.text:
and has a crew of
   about 140 people.

1168.53.text: - And where is it right now?

1170.10.text:
- Right now it is
   deployed overseas

1172.37.text:
on a classified mission.
  - [Matt] Can't tell us that.

1174.24.text:
- [Stuart] and I have
 to leave it at that.

1175.97.text:
But they're doing great
work, I know that.

1179.14.text:
What's the, and maybe
 you can't answer this,

1180.95.text:
were you ever in a
situation in your career

1182.81.text:
where things got
   dicey in terms of,

1185.95.text:
or is that something
 you can't talk about,

1189.66.text:
or another sub in the
   area, that kind of thing?

1191.96.text:
Just a, like you talk
 about, a forward area.

1197.06.text:
- Yeah, anytime you
  spend your career

1198.93.text:
doing something
  that is this complex

1201.53.text:
and operating in
 forward areas, things,

1204.77.text:
you're gonna run
  into circumstances
  that are stressful.

1207.74.text:
And I certainly have
  been through that.

1209.24.text:
Fortunately they
  all turned out well,

1211.48.text:
otherwise I wouldn't be here
  as Admiral in active duty.

1216.65.text:
Most of those were all
 classified missions,

1219.22.text:
as you might imagine, so
it's a little difficult

1221.75.text:
to talk about
  those, but a lot of

1227.26.text:
- Tell me about your
  pistol shooting,

1229.56.text:
cause that was something you
 really got into at Annapolis,

1232.43.text:
and you went to the
 Olympics, tell us about that.

1234.43.text:
- Well, I didn't
  go to the Olympics.

1236.94.text:
- I tried out.
  - [Matt] Almost, OK, sorry.

1239.20.text:
- That was just one of
 those unusual things.

1242.04.text:
Track was my best sport
   when I was in high school,

1245.48.text: and I thought maybe when I went

1246.91.text:
to the Naval Academy,
 I could do that.

1249.72.text:
I discovered that in my class
 alone at the Naval Academy

1252.85.text:
were four state champion milers,
and not from small states.

1257.99.text:
I think it was South Carolina,
 Michigan and Florida.

1262.66.text:
Florida or New
  York, so big states.

1267.23.text:
Well, anyway, all the midshipmen
receive missile training

1269.60.text:
while they're with
  small arms training.

1271.47.text:
- And they like you
 to try a sport, right?

1272.67.text: Isn't that part of, you have to?

1274.11.text:
- Yeah, exactly, and the
training turned out well

1276.88.text:
and I thought well maybe
I'll give that a hand,

1278.64.text:
and it turned out I just had
  a natural affinity for that.

1281.91.text:
And they have a very strong
 program at the Naval Academy.

1284.28.text:
When I was there,
 they were in the midst

1291.42.text:
And while I was there,
we experienced one loss

1295.16.text:
my sophomore year, first
match of the season.

1297.90.text:
And we won everything else
   the rest of my time there,

1300.03.text:
and that was the beginning
   of what became the longest

1302.10.text:
win streak of any sport
   in Naval Academy history.

1305.80.text:
57 consecutive wins, so on
   par with Bison football.

1312.14.text:
Is that pretty intense,
those competitions?

1318.32.text:
- Yeah, and it's a lot
 of mental training,

1320.75.text:
which makes it a little
bit of a different sport

1323.06.text:
compared to the others,
and you'll often find

1325.29.text:
that the best shooters
 are a little bit older

1331.83.text:
are actually the two pistol
  shooters on our team.

1334.93.text:
So back when I was just
finished my junior year,

1338.17.text:
I was invited to
  the Olympic trials.

1341.61.text:
And we made a good showing,
  but we didn't make the team.

1344.68.text:
- I've got three, four
 minutes left here in our show.

1347.48.text:
Why is the Navy still
  important in today's world?

1351.55.text:
- It's vital because,
 again, we're out there

1353.35.text:
on the front lines with the
 presence of the United States.

1357.59.text:
We're deterring conflict,
   and should conflict win,

1360.33.text:
we're ready to, conflict
   occur, we're ready to win.

1364.50.text:
And that is, again,
assuring to the allies.

1368.07.text:
And so that helps
   prevent arms races

1372.70.text:
And we also keep the sea
  lanes of communication open,

1375.57.text:
so about 80% of the
   nation's economic activity

1379.44.text:
actually is transported
over the oceans.

1382.35.text:
And in past years, there's
   been piracy in the area

1386.59.text: of the Gulf of Aden off Somalia

1389.42.text:
that had great effect
 on merchant traffic.

1391.92.text: And then we brought in the Navy

1395.89.text:
we stabilized that, and so
   things that are bulk goods

1399.43.text:
are very dependent
  on shipping by sea.

1402.17.text:
That's important to this
  region because that's where

1404.04.text:
our agricultural products
   get shipped overseas.

1407.64.text:
So the livelihood of many
people around here is ultimately

1410.41.text:
dependent on the security
   provided by the Navy.

1413.18.text:
- Do we still have the
best navy in the world?

1417.45.text:
I know there's been
  some chit chat.

1418.72.text:
I know, you know, you
 work in the Pentagon.

1420.72.text:
You're close to the
   political arena out there.

1423.89.text:
There's been some
  talk about, I know,

1427.69.text:
Any periphery
  there with the Navy

1429.59.text:
that you guys are
  paying attention to

1431.20.text:
or possible cuts
 coming or how is that

1435.77.text:

   the office that oversees

1437.20.text:
the entire DoD budget, which
  is in debate right now.

1442.34.text:
- [Matt] But they get on
Capitol Hill talking about this.

1446.55.text:
- Are there places to cut,
   you know, where there's,

1449.78.text:
we can't cut too
  much of course cause

1451.48.text:
we need the Navy out there,
  but say what you can say.

1455.09.text:
- At this point all
  cuts are difficult.

1457.32.text:
Easy choices were
 made a long time ago,

1463.33.text:
of the American public
 and the taxpayer

1465.40.text:
and what they do for
  the Armed Forces,

1467.63.text:
and in return I think we're
  a good investment for them

1471.30.text:
for security and
   stability for the country.

1474.37.text:
And our leaders are
   working hard on the issue

1476.88.text:
in conjunction with
Congress, and ultimately

1479.58.text:
trying to do the right thing
  for the American people.

- In the few minutes we have
  left, just a quick question

1485.62.text:
to you about what's the
biggest misconception

1488.25.text:
you think the public has about
 the Navy or a Naval career?

1494.19.text:
And that's part of
 the education process

1495.59.text:
that you're here
to do, you know.

1497.00.text:
- Probably not familiar with
  what a career looks like

1500.10.text: and the fact that you alternate

1501.57.text: between sea duty and shore duty.

1504.37.text:
So you'd be assigned
 a ship or a submarine,

1507.94.text:
and typically three,
 four years at a time.

1511.48.text:
And then you'll
   have a shore duty

1512.74.text: that's two or three years long.

1514.75.text:
So that balances the time
   you're away from home

1517.48.text:
and the time that
   you do get to be

1521.95.text:
And while you're at
home, you're building up

1523.36.text:
your skill sets,
  learning new things.

1526.16.text:
Oftentimes a college education
 for the enlisted force.

1533.57.text:
And get yourself ready
  again for another sea duty.

if people are interested

1538.20.text:
in Naval career or finding

where's the best

Is there a website
  or office in Fargo?

1546.75.text:
is a great website to go to,

for recruiting this
